Graphical abstract The Fischer–Tropsch process is a technical route for the indirect liquefaction of coal in the modern coal chemical industry and also an important means of producing high-value-added products in the coal chemical industry. The market demand for the main product Fischer–Tropsch wax (n-alkane content up to 95 %) is limited, resulting in an overcapacity. The hydroisomerization process can transform Fischer–Tropsch waxes into a low-freezing-point oil-phase mixtures, which can be used as a high-end lubricating base oils to solve the imbalance between supply and demand in the market and expand the comprehensive utilization of coal chemical resources. However, the complex synergistic effects between metal and acid sites and the diffusion limitations of olefin intermediates are major challenges in the design of the bifunctional catalysts. Unlike the majority of studies that focused on analyzing the isomerization functions of acidic carriers, in this review, we focused on the types of metal sites and the factors affecting the metal function of bifunctional catalysts used in n-alkane hydroisomerization in recent years. We introduce bifunctional catalysts supporting different metal types, including noble metals, transition metals and their compounds, bimetallic sites, and other catalyst types. In particular, the “doping effect” of the second metal is, for the first time, proposed to explain its role on the catalyst body, and the effects of the metal particle size and dispersion, crystal plane orientation, metal/acid site ratio, and the distance between the metal and acid sites on the hydrogenation function are also discussed. The summary of previous research shows that the types and structural control of metal sites have greatly improved the performance of n-alkane hydroisomerization over bifunctional catalysts. This provides an important reference for the structural design of new bifunctional catalysts in the future and for catalyst application in the hydroisomerization of Fischer–Tropsch waxes. Keywords Hydroisomerization Bifunctional catalyst n-Alkane Fischer–Tropsch wax Metal function 1 Introduction Green and environmentally friendly energy development solutions have become a trend of the energy sector, and various green energy facilities have been developed. Numerous countries are successively introducing policies and regulations related to energy conservation, emission reduction, and green chemistry to protect the environment and ecology. Nevertheless, to date, fossil fuels including coal and petroleum have remained the main energy sources in modern industry and transportation [1]. This has forced the traditional energy industry to seek a compromise, while not significantly affecting today’s energy structure, and to complete the transformation of corporate strategies and green production processes. Among such production processes, the direct liquefaction and indirect liquefaction of coal and the alkylation and isomerization of petroleum hydrocarbons are popular breakthroughs. Moreover, as gasoline regulations become increasingly complex, from the perspective of fossil fuels, meeting the requirements of high fuel quality and energy efficiency is urgent [2,3]. The Fischer–Tropsch (F–T) process is a pivotal gas liquefaction technology used for producing synthetic lubricants and fuels from coal, natural gas, and biomass [4]. This process can produce a synthetic liquid fuel of extremely high purity, composed of linear alkanes and olefins and free of sulfur, nitrogen, aromatics, and metal elements. The synthetic oil is then further refined to produce environmentally friendly fuel oil and chemicals, such as diesel, naphtha, soft wax, and F–T wax. Not only can the obtained oil be used as raw materials for low-sulfur diesel to solve the problems of supply and costs associated with petroleum hydrocarbons, but F–T wax, the downstream product of the F–T process, can be used as the stock for high-end lubricating base oils. Among the products of F–T process and subsequent hydroisomerization treatment, C4–C7 short-chain n-alkanes can be converted into iso-alkanes with high octane numbers for use as fuel gasoline. C8–C15 long-chain n-alkanes can reduce the freezing point while increasing the cetane number of diesel and jet fuel, and F–T wax with a carbon number above 15 can also be used to reduce the pour point to obtain lubricating oil with decent low-temperature fluidity. Compared with petroleum wax derived from crude oil, F–T products have a wider carbon number distribution and a higher n-alkane content, reaching 95 %. Moreover, the fuel produced by the hydroisomerization of F–T wax has higher octane and cetane numbers. F–T wax is first cracked and converted into waxy fractions with appropriate molecular weight ranges and then isomerized to lower the pour point. The viscosity index of the isomerized base oil is lower than those of paraffin (close to 170) but still higher than that of class IV oil poly-α-olefins (PAOs). Moreover, F–T base oil does not contain sulfur, nitrogen, cyclic hydrocarbons, and aromatics [4], which not only causes the base oil to have a high viscosity index and low volatility but also reduces the number of hydrogen atoms on benzyl and tertiary groups, so that the oxidation resistance is improved. The main components of F–T wax and petroleum wax are shown in Scheme 1 . Table 1 [5] compares the properties and composition of the base oils of categories II to IV under the classification of American Petroleum Institute (API) at a certain viscosity. The most widely accepted reaction mechanism of n-alkane hydroisomerization is the bifunctional monomolecular mechanism when the metal function and acid function of the catalyst are balanced [6–8]. Taking n-heptane hydroisomerization as an example, as shown in Scheme 2 , the reaction process is as follows: 1) the n-alkane is dehydrogenated at metal sites to generate an n-olefin intermediate (path A); 2) the n-olefin intermediate is protonated at Brønsted acid sites (BASs) to breed an alkylcarbenium ion (path B); 3) the mono- or multi-branched alkylcarbenium ion can be generated by skeleton rearrangement at BASs (path F); 4) a branched alkylcarbenium ion is deprotonated at the BASs (path H) and then hydrogenated at the metal sites to become an iso-alkane (path I), or β-scission occurs to generate cracked products (path G). Compared to proceeding paths C and D, the alkylcarbonium ions can be produced by adding protons to n-alkanes, the formation of the alkylcarbenium ion is much easier through paths A and B. The olefin intermediate in the BAS and the alkylcarbenium ion undergo competitive adsorption–desorption (path E) [9]. The (de)protonation and skeleton rearrangement processes at the BAS are also summarized into several major isomerization mechanism hypotheses, including the mechanisms of the type A and type B isomerization of alkylcarbenium ions, shape-selective (shape-selection of reactants, products, and intermediates) isomerization in pores, and the “pore mouth”-type and “key-lock”-type mechanisms [10]. In addition, when the catalysts with strong Brønsted acidity insufficiently balanced by metal function, the monofunctional bimolecular mechanism predominates, and its proportion in the overall reaction decreases with the growth of the nMs/nAs ratio (the ratio of the entire number of bare metal sites to the total number of BASs) [11]. It is evident from the mechanism of bifunctional catalysis that developing a bifunctional catalyst with an excellent performance is especially important to obtain a considerable yield of isomers via n-alkane hydroisomerization. In fact, both theoretical experiments and industrial applications have been carried out following this idea. The bifunctional catalyst is composed of metal sites in the catalytic (de)hydrogenation process and acid sites in the catalytic (de)protonation and framework rearrangement processes. After decades of research, it has been observed that species of the transition metals Pt, Pd, and Ni are often used as metal sites. The BASs are generally responsible for materials with suitable acidity, such as silicoaluminophosphates (SAPO-series molecular sieve) [12–14], zeolites (β, ZSM series, mordenite, USY, and USDY) [11,15–18], amorphous silica-alumina (SiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2-Al2O3) [19–21], mesoporous materials (MCM-41, MCM-48, and AlMCM-41) [22–24], superacid solids (WO3-ZrO2 and S2O8 2−/ZrO2-Al2O3) [25,26], and acidic ionic liquids (Et3NHCl-AlCl3, [HMIM]HSO4, and [HMBIM]HSO4) [27–29]. In the practical industry, amorphous silica-alumina (ASA) or other mixed oxides are the preferred commercial catalysts [30]. A series of correlative patents granted by ExxonMobil, Shell and Chevron use ASA or a mixture of refractory oxides as catalyst carriers [31–36]. Although there are few BASs due to the structural disorder of ASA, the catalytic activity can be modified by improving the acidity of ASA. Because of its own characteristics of providing a considerable mesoporous network and maintaining a large reaction interface, it can well catalyze the hydroconversion of long-chain alkanes and even F–T wax [21]. Therefore, in general, a bifunctional catalyst is a functional composite material composed of active metal nanoparticles supported on acidic materials. Since the (de)hydrogenation process is very rapid, the rate-determining step of this process is generally the rearrangement step of alkylcarbenium ions that occurs on acidic supports. Multiple studies associated with several types of acidic carriers, controllable structures, adjustable acidity, and many other easy-to-control features have focused on the modification of acidic carriers and the development of new carriers. The metal function, which represents one of the dual functions, has been relatively less studied by researchers than the acid function. Often, the metal function is given attention only when the metal–acid synergy and the intimate distance between the two sites are studied, with a focus on the acid function. However, there are reasons for this: (de)hydrogenation is a rapid and dynamic process, and the hydroisomerization reaction is carried out in a special reactor in the presence of hydrogen, which increases the difficulty of employing dynamic characterization methods. The exploration and modification of active metals are much more limited compared with those of a wide variety of acidic carriers. Therefore, researchers are more inclined to study the acid function. Nonetheless, this does not mean that the metal function is not important or worth studying and discussing. On the contrary, when we reviewed related articles, we found that the role of the metal function in the hydroisomerization process and the attributes that can be studied are indistinguishable from those of the acid function, especially for the synthesis of metal species with higher activities, a balance of the metal–acid functions, and intimacy criterion. For example, Ramaker and Kubička et al. [37,38] found that the charge of the oxygen atom of the carrier changed due to the interaction between the metal and the acid carrier, and pointed out that "the strength of the proton-oxygen bond of the bridging hydroxyl group will also change". Sachtler et al. [39–42] proposed that metal clusters and zeolite protons can interact to form fairly stable metal-proton [Pt n H]+ and [Pd n H]+ adducts as bifunctional hybrid sites, which they call "collapsed bifunctional sites". The isomerization of n-paraffins is carried out on these adducts without the transfer of intermediates between metal and acid sites, as all reaction steps can be achieved during a single residence period. Paál et al. [43,44] and Garin et al. [45,46] had also been verified this statement proposed by the preceding authors. Some studies have also focused on the effect of metal modification on the strength of BASs in zeolites. It is found that noble metals in bifunctional catalysts participate in the charge transfer with adjacent skeleton atoms, thus affecting the average skeleton electronegativity of zeolites studied. This effect changes the acid strength of Al–OH–Si groups [47–49]. Since there are still many technical barriers in the hydroisomerization of F-T wax. Based on the summary and analysis of the hydroisomerization cases of petroleum-derived wax or oil, the aim of this paper is to find some reference material to enable the design of new catalysts that can be applied to the hydroisomerization of F-T waxes in the future. Moreover, unlike previous reports that focused on the catalytic mechanism over bifunctional catalysts, especially on acidic supports, this review focuses on the effects of the types and structural control of the metal sites during n-alkane hydroisomerization. In addition to Pt, Pd, and Ni, other active metal components are worth considering. From the perspective of the metal function, this review discusses which variables will significantly impact the overall performances of bifunctional catalysts to provide alternative inspiration for the design of ideal catalysts. 2 Different metal species supported on bifunctional catalysts for n-alkane hydroisomerization In this section, the types and functions of metal species in bifunctional catalysts are discussed from three perspectives. The first category is monometallic species as functional sites, including common noble metals, transition metals, and their compounds. The second is the combination of multiple metal species as (de)hydrogenation sites. For example, noble metal–transition metal materials designed to reduce the production cost are combined into metal sites. These two parts are competitive research subjects. In addition, the “doping effect” is also proposed to explain the performance improvements of bifunctional catalysts over inactive (or very low active) metals applied solely in the field of hydroisomerization, especially some transition metals and rare-earth metals such as lanthanum. The types of metal sites mentioned in this section are presented in Table 2 . 2.1 Catalyst metal function based on single metals 2.1.1 Noble metal–based catalysts Owing to their powerful (de)hydrogenation functions and superior stabilities, noble metals such as Pt and Pd are still the most extensively used metal components for bifunctional catalysts in the industrialized adhibition of n-paraffin hydroisomerization [67]. However, the difference in Pt and Pd microstructures results in a slightly different mechanisms for catalyzing n-alkane (de)hydrogenation and consequently different catalytic performances. Liu et al. [68] ion-exchanged β zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 25) at 353 K in Pt(NH3)4Cl2 and Pd(NH3)4Cl2 solutions to prepare Pd/β and Pt/β catalysts containing 0.5 wt% Pd and 0.5 wt% Pt, respectively. The F-T reaction and the n-alkane isomerization processes were combined to illustrate the distinctions of Pd/β and Pt/β catalysts. Surprisingly, the Pt/β catalyst was rapidly deactivated, and the performance of the Pd/β catalyst was stable. Because the overall process was divided into upper F-T reactions and lower isomerization reactions, the CO conversion in the upper reactor was about 55 %, indicating that a considerable amount of unreacted CO was present. CO moved from the upper reactor to the lower one, and the partial pressure was high. The molecular adsorption of CO mainly occurred on metals such as Pt, Pd, and Ir in the late 4d and 5d orbits [69]. Moreover, previous studies found that the adsorbed CO can poison the catalytic activity of the ethylene hydrogenation reaction by interrupting the function of Pt [70]. CO can be used as a probe molecule to distinguish the hydrogen adsorption of Pt and Pd. Since the competitive adsorption of CO with H2 at the Pt sites reduces the metal function of Pt, the metal and acid balance of the Pt/β catalyst is disrupted, which is the major reason for rapid inactivation of the catalyst. However, this problem can be solved by increasing the Pt load or introducing additional hydrogen partial pressure to increase the adsorption of H2 relative to CO. Although Pd also adsorbs CO in the form of molecules [71], independent CO and H adsorption islands occur on Pd (111) generated during the co-adsorption of the mixed gas of CO and H2. In addition, H in Pd is easily formed in the presence of CO [72]. Therefore, the metal function of Pd is not destroyed by the CO adsorption. Because of the high mobility of the metal Pd, it can be used as an H reservoir, resulting in the existence of H islands and large blocks of H in the catalyst. Due to the sufficient number of active sites, the synergistic effect of adjacent atoms, and the strong interaction with the carrier, atomic clusters have become one of the most interesting and attractive subjects. Analyses have shown that metal clusters have the potential for (de)hydrogenation reactions, which are crucial for the isomerization of n-alkanes. However, the strong interaction between the metal precursor and carrier hinders the migration and aggregation of Pt during the reduction process. In the actual process, the gas resistance in the channel will hinder the effective adsorption of the metal precursor on the porous support, which will cause a weak interaction between the carrier and metal precursor, enabling the aggregation and generation of bulky particles during the reduction process. Covering certain acid sites, in addition to reducing the Pt catalytic activity, is not conducive to effective synergy. Wang et al. [54] proposed a novel strategy to solve the migration and agglomeration problem. The appropriate catalyst was obtained by removing the gas in the porous support channel. They used the “vacuum-assisted” strategy shown in Fig. 1 to fix the highly dispersed trace Pt clusters (particle size ≈ 1 nm) on SAPO-11, and the excess gas in the channel was exhausted before the metal precursor contacted the carrier. Due to strong capillary action, Pt clusters will be adsorbed in large quantities near the pores, which will help block the Pt migration and aggregation during the reduction process. Through a vacuum-assisted strategy to promote effective contact between Pt clusters and BAS on the support, a high BAS density (more isomerization active sites) and a considerable nMs/nAs (better balance of metal and acid function) were obtained, which are the characteristics of an ideal hydroisomerization catalyst. Therefore, although only a small quantity of Pt clusters (0.15 wt%, or even lower, 0.035 wt%) was supported on SAPO-11, it still had excellent catalytic activity and stability (isomer selectivity was about 94.4 % at 94.3 % conversion) after a 120-h test of the hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane and catalytic diesel oil (crude oil with complex composition), better than those of the catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method (88 % isomer selectivity at 90 % conversion). This process reduced the freezing point of n-C16 and catalytic diesel oil by as much as 40 °C. Based on the discussion above, the process has guiding significance for industrial applications and noble metal load reduction. The obtained catalyst is also one of the most “ideal” hydroisomerization catalysts found in theoretical research to date. In the study of Pd as the active metal sites for bifunctional catalysts, Song et al. [50] prepared a series of X Pd/SAPO-11 ( X refers to the mass fraction of Pd) catalysts by a hydrothermal method using dibutylamine as a template, and the two active sites had different positions and proportions. They declared that the activity and selectivity of Pd/SAPO-11 catalyst in n-decane hydroisomerization depend on the nMs/nAs ratio and the number of effective acid sites (Nas) between two metal sites, which was first proposed by Batalha and Guisnet et al. [73,74], the Nas value to quantify the average number of basic steps of acid catalysis between two nearby metal sites entangled in the conversion of a reactant molecule. Based on the calculated values of the mono-branched isomers and multi-branched isomers as well as the cleavage products of the reaction output on the bifunctional catalyst, the Nas value was found to decrease with an increase in the Pd loading. As the Pd loading is increased, the density of Pd distribution on the carrier will increase, and the quantity of BAS between the metal sites will decrease. The results showed that when the Pd loading amount was in the range of 0.05 to 0.5 wt%, the average diameter of the Pd particles changed slightly. Although there was no significant sintering, the hydrogen chemisorption measurements of the catalyst revealed that with the enhancement of the Pd loading, the dispersion of Pd on SAPO-11 decreased, demonstrating that the metal particles with high Pd contents had agglomerated. The (de)hydrogenation process was the rate-limiting step of the bifunctional pathway. A low Pd loading did not afford enough metal sites to enable the effective dehydrogenation of n-C10 and the hydrogenation process of olefin intermediates. As a result, the acid catalysis between the two metal sites increased, and cracking was more likely to occur than hydrogenation. While 0.5 wt% Pd/SAPO-11 had the highest nMs/nAs (0.47) and the smallest Nas value (1.39), more Pd particles would obstruct the channels and pores of SAPO-11 molecular sieves, leading to the suppressed diffusion of branched isomers, consequently exacerbating the secondary cracking. Only the Pd/SAPO-11 catalysts with 0.1 or 0.3 wt% Pd of concentration have provided an adequate nMs/nAs and Nas values (0.09 ≤ nMs/nAs ≤ 0.27, Nas ∼ 1.5); the Pd particle size was uniform and well dispersed, which could balance the activity of the BAS in the conversion of olefin intermediates. After isomerization at the BAS, branched olefins were rapidly hydrogenated at the metal sites to produce the corresponding branched iso-alkanes and diffuse efficiently at the BASs. Therefore, the maximum iso-C10 selectivity of 89.8 % was obtained over the 0.3 wt% Pd/SAPO-11 catalyst, with an n-C10 conversion of 90.8 % [50]. In summary, both noble metals Pt and Pd show excellent functions for n-alkane hydroisomerization. However, in deciding which of these two metals is the optimal choice, other parameters of the overall catalyst and the characteristics of the catalyzed reactants should be comprehensively considered. Thus, we cannot arbitrarily and precisely decide that Pt or Pd creates the best metal sites for n-alkane hydroisomerization. However, in general, Pt as a metal site is indeed more widely applied in research than Pd, even though Pd has better potential application value than Pt due to its special structural properties. 2.1.2 Transition metal–based catalysts Although noble metals are widely used in the theoretical research of the active sites on hydroisomerization catalysts, the practical use of noble metals in industry faces economic issues that leads to the limited use of such catalysts. In the application of some bifunctional catalysts, the use of chlorinated alumina catalysts facilitated by Pt also causes severe corrosion and environmental pollution issues because of the requirement of the consecutive addition of chlorine gas [75]. Therefore, the alternative to using inexpensive transition metals as metal sites is also a research focus in this field. In previous studies, many attempts have been made to develop transition metal–based bifunctional catalysts, which could greatly reduce the economic cost [76–81]. Among them, Ni, since it belongs the same group (group VIII) as the noble metal Pt and Pd, has many similarities in atomic structure to these metals. Moreover, it has been extensively studied and even applied in actual production. Among the non-noble metals, Ni can be considered to have shown the greatest activity as the (de)hydrogenation active sites for n-alkane hydroisomerization [76,78–80]. However, since the (de)hydrogenation activity of Ni is lower than that of noble metals, it is necessary to increase the Ni loading amount in actual operation to overcome the problem of a lower overall activity. Increasing the Ni amount will not cause an economic burden, because the price of Ni is about one-thousandth that of Pt. However, whether a large amount of Ni can stably exist without large particle agglomeration under harsh treatment conditions has become a problem that must be considered when Ni is employed for production. The noble metal Pt is considered as an example. Since Pt is a heavy element with high polarizability and atomic weight, Pt atoms have a favorable van der Waals interaction with the pore wall of the zeolite, so they can be loaded in the zeolite pores in the form of tiny nanoparticles [55]. In contrast, the lighter element Ni has a weak polarizability and weak interaction with the pore walls. Ni atoms tend to migrate to the surfaces of traditional zeolite crystals with very low external surface areas and assemble to form bulky agglomerates, thus displaying poor dispersibility. Moreover, the loaded Ni particles maintain long distances from the internal acid sites of the zeolites. The distance between the two active sites will also harm the overall catalyst. These are the reasons that the use of non-noble metals to replace noble metals in the isomerization process poses significant challenges. Fortunately, there have been some research breakthroughs in terms of finding some novel preparation strategies to reduce the particle sizes of non-noble metals, thereby enhancing the interactions between the metal and the carrier to suppress the metal aggregation problem [82,83]. Several experiments have been performed, including the introduction of additives [84,85] or the use of different kinds of metal precursors [24,86] to inhibit metal particle aggregation and the use of weakly polar solvent impregnation methods to synthesize bifunctional catalysts [87–89]. For example, in one study, a Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst synthesized using ethanol as a solvent was used to produce nickel monoxide particles with sizes of 20 nm, which were much smaller than the corresponding particles (50 nm) when water was used as the solvent [90]. In a different study, Kim et al. [55] used a self-developed polyamine surfactant as a mesoporous/microporous dual-structure-directing agent to synthesize a sponge-like nanozeolite. The nanozeolite was composed of a disordered 2.5-nm-thick MFI molecular sieve crystal skeleton. Despite the disordered arrangement of the skeleton structure, the zeolite still had slit-shaped mesopores with an extremely consistent diameter. Only 2 wt% Ni could be added to attain a performance equivalent to that of an MFI zeolite containing 1 wt% Pt. Owing to the restriction or clamping effect of the zeolite mesoporous walls on the Ni nanoparticles, the highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles were stabilized. Despite the low Ni loading, the Ni/nanozeolite catalyst showed a better isomer yield (about 70 %) than those of Pt-based catalysts. Lyu et al. [56] designed a one-pot synthesis strategy (Fig. 2 a) for SAPO-11 synthesis in which the Ni source was ground with an amorphous precursor, thereby avoiding the use of additional solvents during the synthesis. The Ni in the obtained Ni/SAPO-11 was highly dispersed, and the metal sites and BAS formed instantaneously. The Ni framework provided a synergistic effect between the metal sites and BAS, and the metal–acid function achieved great balance. Compared with the traditional Pt/SAPO-11, the synthesized Ni/SAPO-11 showed a commensurate catalytic performance, as shown in Fig. 2b [56]. There are also related reports on the hydroconversion of Ni-based catalysts using other mesoporous materials as carriers. Fang et al. [91] used several AlMCM-41 samples prepared from different aluminum sources as the carrier for Ni-based catalysts, and found that NaAlO2-derived AlMCM-41 is a highly efficient catalyst for the n-dodecane hydroconversion. Lanzafame et al. [92] studied the effect of the mesoporosity introduction on the hydroconversion of n-hexadecane over Ni/H-MFI, Ni/Hβ and Ni/ASA catalysts by controlled desilication and indicated that the introduction of mesoporosity in Hβ could increase the activity while maintaining good selectivity for the most relevant isomers. 2.1.3 Catalysts based on transition metal compounds (phosphates, borides, oxides, and sulfides) In view of the economic benefits, many catalytic systems have been studied in which transition metals are used as active metal sites to replace noble metals over bifunctional catalysts. Although the cost of the bifunctional catalyst will be greatly reduced and the catalytic performance is considerable, the relatively low isomerization selectivity and weak toxicity resistance have forced researchers to pursue more complicated preparation processes to improve the catalyst performance and offset these disadvantages. This procedure does not meet the requirements of green chemistry and thus, to some degree, limits the application of Ni-based bifunctional catalysts. Besides transition metals, compounds of transition metals have also been found to exhibit catalytic properties for n-alkane hydroisomerization and are an option [22,57–60,93–95]. For example, transition metal phosphide has great chemical stability and remarkable thermal and electrical conductivities, and it is expected to become the next-generation hydroconversion catalyst for oil refining [96]. In particular, phosphides are highly active catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and hydrodenitrogenation [97,98], such as in the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde [99], deoxygenation of methyl laurate [100], hydrolysis of naphthalene [101], and water–gas shift reaction [102]. It has also been proven to be useful in n-alkane hydroisomerization [57]. As a new type of amorphous alloy catalytic material, metal boride catalysts have attracted increasing attention because of their classical structural characteristics with long-range disorder, distinct isotropic structures, and abundant coordinatively unsaturated sites, which can provide a uniform environment for the dispersion of positive sites [103,104]. These characteristics allow the catalyst to exhibit good activity and selectivity in several hydrogenation processes, such as the hydroconversion of n-alkanes, and they also have important significance for expanding the application of amorphous alloy materials [59]. Transition metal oxides, represented by molybdenum oxide, are also important compounds in catalytic reactions. When molybdenum oxide is applied in n-alkane hydroisomerization, the catalytically active component molybdenum sub-oxide is prepared directly by the partial reduction of MoO3 in a mixed gas flow of hydrogen/n-heptane [60]. In addition, the HDS catalysts used in industry to produce low-sulfur gasoline possess not only great desulfurization capabilities but also the function of framework isomerization, because the olefin saturation of naphtha obtained from fluid catalytic cracking during HDS can cause a significant reduction in the octane number. Transition metal sulfides are used as HDS catalysts to convert linear olefins to branched olefins, and then the hydrogenation to iso-alkanes will minimize the loss of the octane number [22,105]. Therefore, the abovementioned transition metal compounds provide some potential options for reducing the bifunctional catalyst preparation costs. The high selectivity of Ni-based catalysts for hydrocracking due to their structural properties reduces the yield of hydroisomerization products. To improve the isomerization selectivity of Ni-based catalysts, it is necessary to suppress the CC bond hydrogenolysis reaction occurring on the metal sites. Nickel phosphides (such as Ni3P, Ni2P5, and Ni2P) differ from Ni nanoparticles in terms of electronic and geometric properties due to the phosphorus (P) ligands and ensemble effects [106]. These effects explain why Ni2P shows a weaker hydrogenolysis ability of CC bonds [107,108] and preferable tolerance to noxious components compared with Ni [65]. Tian et al. [57] studied the catalytic characteristics of Ni/SAPO-11 and Ni2P/SAPO-11 in the hydroisomerization of n-dodecane and discovered that the iso-dodecane yield of Ni/SAPO-11 (22 %) was significantly lower than that of Ni2P/SAPO-11 (65 %). The results indicated that Ni2P may provide feasible metal sites on bifunctional catalysts, which can further improve the yield of isomer products. The experimental results showed that the Ni loading and Ni/P ratio had a great effect on the yield of iso-dodecane over the Ni2P/SAPO-11. When the Ni2P loading was sustained at 3 wt% as the Ni/P ratio of precursor was decreased, the yield of isomer products increased and reached a maximum when the Ni/P ratio was equal to 1. This phenomenon occurred because as the Ni2P loading grew, more BAS in the SAPO-11 carrier was covered by Ni2P particles, thereby reducing the number of weak- and moderate-intensity acidic sites of SAPO-11. As more P and Ni species are introduced, fewer acid sites of the SAPO-11 are retained. Fortunately, Ni phosphide is weakly acidic and thus provides weak acid sites in the form of Ni δ + sites and POH groups [109,110]. To obtain a high conversion of n-dodecane and selectivity to iso-dodecane, it is necessary to strike a balance between a medium acid site and a Ni2P site. Liu et al. [58] prepared a MoP/Hβ catalyst using ammonium nitrate and citric acid as combustion promoters by a low-temperature autoignition method. Owing to the large amount of gas generated during the combustion process, the formation of a uniform and non-agglomerated powder resulted in a catalyst with a high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area, large pore volume, and more strong acid sites. At a reaction temperature of 320 °C, 30 wt% MoP/Hβ catalyzed the hydroisomerization reaction of n-heptane with an isomerization selectivity of 81.7 % at a conversion rate of 55.2 %. Chen et al. [59] adopted the dry mixing method to synthesize amorphous NiB nanoparticles. Their experiments showed that the NiB loading was correlated with the number of strong Lewis acid sites and the ratio of weak acids to strong acids in the sample. Thus, the NiB loading had an impact on the structural properties and acidity of the surface. Furthermore, the calcination temperature of the sample was closely related to the structure of the active component as a metal site. The unloaded amorphous NiB nanoparticles were spherical or chain-shaped with a regular diameter of 30–80 nm and were interconnected. As the particle size decreased, the surface energies of the individual particles became higher. Therefore, the nanoparticles tended to be connected to reduce the surface energy. When the calcination temperature was 200 °C and the NiB loading was 5 wt%, the catalyst had suitable metal sites and surface acid sites to deliver appropriate synergistic effects, accompanied by an isomer yield of 55.6 %. Moreover, the hydroisomerization mechanism of n-hexane on NiB/Hβ was slightly different from the traditional mechanism, as demonstrated in Fig. 3 . Due to the existence of B-Ni-H, the distinct structure of B-Ni-H on the exterior can supply appropriate (de)hydrogenation sites. These sites replace the traditional metal sites, and undergo n-hexane hydroisomerization reactions with the surface acid sites of the carrier. It can be concluded from this mechanism that the high dispersity of B-Ni-H clusters on the surface helped to improve the transfer efficiency and further enhanced the synergistic effect between the two active sites. Using the gel method, Alemán-Vázquez et al. [60] prepared two H2-reduced powdered MoO3 catalysts (Mo-Al-type and Mo-Si-type) bound by silica or alumina and tested their n-heptane hydroisomerization performances. Inserting H atoms into the lattice of MoO3 will lead to the formation of MoO x H y , which is a crucial procedure to create hydroisomerization activity. The acidity and/or basicity of the binder affected the activity of MoO3 as a hydroisomerization catalyst. The results showed that Mo-Si-type catalysts achieved a lower number of cracked products and a higher selectivity of dimethylpentane, but Mo-Al-type catalysts had the highest catalytic activity. In practical applications, Mo-Si-type catalysts have the advantages of higher mechanical strengths and better catalytic performances than unreduced MoO3. Shi et al. [22] prepared MCM-41-loaded sulfided Ni-Mo, Co-Mo, and Ni-W catalysts using the incipient wetness impregnation method and investigated the external acidity of the catalysts before and after sulfurization and the catalytic performance of the skeleton isomerization of n-hexene under HDS conditions. Under HDS conditions, sulfurization significantly enhanced the surface acidity, which was conducive to the n-hexene isomerization. For the HDS reaction of thiophene, the activities of the sulfided Ni-Mo/MCM-41 and Co-Mo/MCM-41 were as good as that of the industrial Co-Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the sulfided Co-Mo/MCM-41 catalyst showed high yields of framework isomerization because of its firm external acidity and comparatively low activity of hydrogenation. Since the sulfided Co-Mo/MCM-41 catalyst exhibited strong activity for the hydroisomerization conversion of linear olefins to iso-alkanes and the reaction of thiophene HDS, it has application potential for the effective HDS of naphtha without a substantial reduction in the octane number. Although this transition metal catalyzed hydroisomerization in the HDS process, it demonstrated that the transition metal sulfides have a certain activity for the (de)hydrogenation reaction and can be applied for n-alkane hydroisomerization under specific working conditions. 2.2 Catalyst metal function based on multi-metallic sites 2.2.1 Catalysts based on double-noble-metal sites As described above, to find a low-cost alternative that can replace the noble metals and that exhibits stable performances in hydroisomerization reactions, transition metals and their phosphides, borides, oxides, and sulfides can be used. The development of new bifunctional catalysts with better performances and low loading of noble metals has been a popular field in industrial research [54]. In the past several years, the application of bimetallic bifunctional catalysts has been considered to be a favorable scheme to accomplish this goal. Because of the close interaction between the two metal constituents, the electronic improvement and geometric arrangement between the two constituents would be modified, and accordingly, the catalyst would exhibit better catalytic performances. Particularly under the circumstance of Pt-Pd catalysts, because the lattice constant and chemical reactivity of Pt and Pd are quite analogous, it is simple to obtain bimetallic sites by chemical or electrochemical methods [1]. Bauer et al. [61] synthesized a series of Pt-Pd/Hβ with different Pt/Pd molar ratios and a total metal loading of 0.8 wt%. Due to the presence of Pd oxides, which are more easily reduced, the Pt-Pd bimetallic sites exhibited greater dispersibility than mono-metal catalysts. This resulted in a more favorable metal–acid equilibrium and superior performance. Nevertheless, when the Pd content exceeded 50 %, the catalytic performance of the bifunctional catalyst decreased, because at such a Pd concentration, the (de)hydrogenation activity of Pd is slightly inferior to that of Pt. After the evaluation of n-hexadecane hydroisomerization, it was found that the stability of the 0.4Pt-0.4Pd/Hβ catalyst was still very high after 60 days of operation, and the iso-hexadecane yield was the highest, with the value of 72.1 %. This was 28.0 % and 11.3 % higher than those of 0.8Pd/Hβ and 0.8 Pt/Hβ, respectively, which were supported by single noble metals. Through a series of characterization analysis, it was confirmed that hydrogen-rich coke was formed in the process of n-alkane hydroisomerization on Pt-Pd/Hβ, and the pore-blocking of carbon sediments could deactivate the catalyst. In addition, it was found that the distribution of the multi-branched iso-hexadecane in the product was much higher than that of the conventional Pt/ZSM-22 catalyst. This was caused by differences in the pore sizes of the two molecular sieves. On this point, Kenmogne et al. [111] also found an interesting phenomenon through the analysis of the distribution of hexadecane cracking products, that is, regardless of the total conversion, the carbon number of the product is centered on C8, and the function distribution is basically symmetrical. It is shown that the hexadecane cleaves preferentially from the middle, which is different from the random probability in the β-cracking model [112]. Similarly, the hydrocracking of n-decane on mesoporous ASA with uniform distribution has also been reported [19]. In these cases, there are some unique pore networks composed of small mesopores (< 6 nm), which seems to increase the activity of carbon in the middle of the carbon chain [111]. For the ZSM-22 molecular sieve, the smaller pores caused the reactions of n-alkanes to only occur at the pore mouth, but the n-alkanes could freely enter and diffuse in the larger channels of the Hβ zeolite. Therefore, the keys to obtaining more competent and stabler catalysts for long-chain alkane hydroisomerization are to further balance the metal–acid function of the metal (de)hydrogenation components and the zeolite components and reduce the generation of hydrogen-rich coke. For the hydroisomerization of long-chain alkanes, the diffusion limitation of olefin intermediates in the catalyst pores must also be considered, which can be solved using mesoporous materials or nanozeolites. To explore the effect of the addition order of two metal species on n-alkane hydroisomerization over bimetallic bifunctional catalysts, Roldan et al. [62] utilized sequential impregnation and co-impregnation methods to prepare Pd*-Pt/β (Pd was added first), Pt*-Pd/β (Pt was added first), and Pt-Pd/β (co-impregnation). Analysis of separate nanoparticles using X-ray absorption spectroscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy revealed the presence of bimetallic species in the samples Pd*-Pt/β (Pd was reduced before Pt impregnation) and the co-impregnated samples Pt-Pd/β, which had positive catalytic activities. Moreover, Pd*-Pt/β, obtained by the first impregnation with Pd, had the highest number of Pt-Pd bonds and the most uniform distribution; thus, it exhibited the highest activity for hydroisomerization. However, no Pt-Pd bonds were found in Pt*-Pd/β, whose catalytic activity was even lower than that of Pt/β, because the double reduction course stimulated the sintering of Pt nanoparticles. Furthermore, in the Pt*-Pd/β, Pd had a lower coordination number and greater dispersion than Pt. Compared with the particles formed in the mono-metal sample Pt/β, Pd had larger particles and a lower dispersion degree. Therefore, the conversion of the catalyst was between those of the Pd/β and Pt/β samples [62]. From this study, it can be concluded that the sequential impregnation process resulting in the formation of bimetals is crucial to fabricate a catalyst that exhibits excellent performances. Fig. 4 shows an atomic-level model of the bimetal nanoparticles generated in each sample containing Pt and Pd, proposed by the authors and based on a similar model given in a previous study [113]. Barrera et al. [114] studied the activity and selectivity of ZrO2-Al2O3-WOx oxide-supported mono- and bi-metallic Pd-Pt catalysts prepared by the sol–gel method via ammonium metatungstate aqueous solution–assisted alkoxide hydrolysis in n-hexane hydroisomerization and tested their activity by applying high-throughput reaction technology. By adding Al to the ZrW mixed oxides, the activity of the Pd/ZrW catalyst in n-hexane hydroisomerization could be improved. However, adding Pt to Pd/ZrAlW did not significantly change the catalyst acidity. The increase in the activities of the bimetallic catalysts Pd-Pt/ZrAlW may have been due to the change in the intrinsic properties of the surface Pd atoms induced by adjacent Pt atoms. 2.2.2 Catalysts based on bimetallic sites: noble metals combined with transition metals and their compounds Although bimetallic sites of Pt-Pd exhibit excellent catalytic performances, the noble metal loading of 0.8 wt% is still relatively high for industrialized applications. To reduce the noble metal loading while stabilizing the catalyst performance, the introduction of transition metals or their compounds to prepare bimetallic bifunctional catalysts has naturally become an option. Recent studies on Pt-Ni bimetallic sites supported on H-USY zeolites have shown that they provide catalytic activities equal to or even superior to that of monometallic catalysts containing Pt [81,115]. Jao et al. [116] synthesized a batch of Ni-Pt/H-MOR bimetallic bifunctional catalysts with different Ni contents and used H2 temperature-programmed reduction and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption to characterize the bimetallic interactions and acidity on mordenite-supported Ni-Pt. The results showed that the conversion of Ni0.5 %-Pt0.26 %/H-MOR in the hydroisomerization of n-hexane and n-heptane and the selectivity toward the di-branched isomers were higher than those of Pt/H-MOR. This was because the introduction of Ni changed the electronic characteristics of the Pt atoms and enhanced the Pt (de)hydrogenation. As for the pure C5–C7 feedstock, the reaction results showed that introducing an appropriate amount of Ni to the Pt-containing catalyst not only inhibited the formation of fuel gas but also promoted the creation of branched isomers. Conversely, as for sulfur-containing feedstock, the Ni-Pt catalyst was deactivated more rapidly, while the fuel gas formation increased. The higher deactivation rate was related to the inferior sulfur tolerance of the catalyst due to the bimetallic interactions of Ni and Pt, and the metal function rapidly vanished because of sulfur poisoning. In addition, Karthikeyan et al. [117] synthesized a batch of Pd-Ni/Y catalysts for n-octane hydroisomerization by impregnating 0.1–0.5 wt% Ni with 0.1 wt% Pd in the initial stage. Based on the results, the reduction temperature of Pd was significantly reduced after Ni addition. The cause of this phenomenon can be explained from two aspects: 1) the interaction between Ni nanoparticles and reduced Pd nanoparticles caused more H to be chemisorbed; 2) the charge transfer of Ni ions made Pd species more reducible. In addition, the dispersibility of the Pd-Ni bimetal particles was superior to that of the individual Pd nanoparticles, leading to a higher BAS coverage and better metal–acid balance. Owing to this enhanced property, the Pd-Ni/Y catalyst exhibited a better catalytic performance than Pd/Y and Ni/Y. For n-decane hydroisomerization, Karthikeyan et al. [63] used ammonia gas temperature-desorption analysis and found that the BAS ion-exchanged with Ni2+. The increased selectivity toward mono- and di-branched isomers indicated that the mechanism involving protonated cyclopropane intermediates existed. Adding up to 0.3 wt% of Ni could increase the n-decane conversion and the isomer selectivity compared with those of the 0.1 wt% Pd/HY. However, further addition of Ni greatly reduced the activity and isomerization selectivity. In addition to zeolites, Eswaramoorthi et al. [118] prepared a batch of bifunctional catalysts on SAPO-11 and SAPO-5 acidic supports by loading Ni-Pt bimetallic sites. The Pt loading in these catalysts was only 0.2 wt%, while the Ni loading was from 0 to 0.6 wt%. Based on the results of n-hexane hydroisomerization, the Pt-Ni catalysts, especially Pt-Ni0.4, showed better catalytic performances than catalysts containing only Pt. Nevertheless, the bimetallic nanoparticles of the Pt-Ni catalyst with 0.6 wt% Ni loading featured an increase in size to approximately 10 nm, which was significantly larger than the size of the Pt-Ni0.4 catalyst (6 nm). At such a bulky size, due to the presence of unreduced Ni, the metal function was reduced. Therefore, the isomer yield was also low. These studies indicate that there is a suitable range of Ni loading when preparing bimetallic bifunctional catalysts [52]. As mentioned above, solving the problem of catalyst resistance to toxicity by using transition metal compounds as substitutes for noble metals has become the focus of many researchers. To further enhance the catalytic properties of the catalyst, researchers are gradually considering a scheme of adding transition metal compounds to the metal sites of noble metal catalysts. Yao et al. [65] synthesized Pt/Hβ, Ni2P/Hβ, and Pt-Ni2P/Hβ bifunctional catalysts by supporting diverse amounts of Pt on Ni2P/Hβ and studied the catalyst performances for n-heptane hydroisomerization. The results showed that among all the catalysts, 0.1Pt-30Ni2P/Hβ exhibited the highest selectivity to iso-heptane (91.5 %), and the conversion of n-heptane was 55.9 %, which indicated that the addition of a small amount of Pt species to produce bimetallic sites with Ni2P could significantly boost the catalytic properties. Zhang et al. [66] prepared Pd, Ni2P, and bimetallic Pd-Ni2P on SAPO-31 molecular sieves with a dibutylamine template by impregnation or impregnation combined with temperature-programmed reduction methods to prepare a series of bifunctional catalysts. Catalysts Pd/SAPO-31, 4Ni2P/SAPO-31, and 0.05Pd-4Ni2P/SAPO-31 were tested by n-hexadecane hydroisomerization. After metal loading, the crystallinity of the molecular sieves decreased, which may have been due to the framework structure defects caused by the metal loading. When the metal was supported by the incipient wetness impregnation strategy, the acidity of the precursor likely mildly damaged the texture of the SAPO-31 carrier, resulting in a mesopore volume of the Me/SAPO-31 that was greater than that of the SAPO-31 carrier. Moreover, as the metal load increased, the pore openings became more severely blocked, resulting in a gradual decline in the micropore external area and volume of the catalyst. When a trace amount of Pd was loaded with Ni2P, electronic reciprocity occurred between Pd and Ni2P. Thus, the fixation of the bimetal particles on the SAPO-31 carrier was stronger. The increased stability was reflected by the high conversion and selectivity (>80 % and >90 %, respectively) of the 0.05Pd-4Ni2P/SAPO-31 catalyst despite the long-term testing of 100 h. These results were attributed to the following two effects: 1) the presence of Pd could readily inhibit the oxidation of Ni2P species, and the (de)hydrogenation activity of Pd–Ni2P was improved because of the increase in the Niδ+ allocation; 2) electron transfer from Ni2P to Pd and stronger reciprocity between Pd–Ni2P and the SAPO-31 support [66]. Therefore, the 0.05Pd–4Ni2P/SAPO-31 catalyst had a higher metal dispersion and nMs/nAs (which here was CMe/CH+) ratio. Bimetallic bifunctional catalysts have a better balance between the metal and acid functions than monometallic catalysts. The authors also quantitatively discussed the effect of the metal–acid balance and proposed a mechanism of hydroisomerization on bimetallic bifunctional catalysts with different nMs/nAs ratios (Fig. 5 ). When the nMs/nAs ratio was low, the hydroisomerization over the catalyst followed an “unbalanced” parallel mechanism (Scheme a). The main products were mono-branched isomers, multi-branched isomers, and cracked products. When the nMs/nAs ratio was high, the number of multi-branched isomers and cracked products was negligible, and the hydroisomerization followed an ideal continuous mechanism (Scheme b). Through this scheme, olefin intermediates tend to generate mono-branched isomers by hydrogenation at metal sites rather than further conversion at acid sites. This offers a guiding significance for the mechanism of action of bimetallic bifunctional catalysts used in long-chain n-alkane hydroisomerization [66]. The metal sites cited in Sections 2.2.1 and 2.2.2 are currently the most common types in theoretical research. Through the analysis of the (de)hydrogenation course at the metal sites and its impact on the overall catalyst, the advantages and disadvantages of each metal site are summarized Table 3 . 2.2.3 Catalysts based on double-non-noble-metal sites and trimetallic sites As mentioned above, the formation of bimetallic sites on bifunctional catalysts is also an effective approach for improving the catalytic performance and reducing the preparation costs. However, bimetallic sites are generally produced by combining noble metals with high catalytic performances and low-cost, non-noble transition metals. In addition, researchers have explored the combination of two non-noble transition metals. The catalytic performances of the bifunctional catalysts may be improved by even introducing trimetallic sites. Rezgui et al. [119–122] explored the properties of Ni-tungsten-based, bimetallic, bifunctional catalysts in isomerization reactions through a series of experiments. First, they found that Ni-WO x could exhibit a specific behavior in catalytic dewaxing. Then, to enhance the selectivity of the Ni-WO x -based catalyst for the isomerization reaction, a third metal Pt was supported on an ASA carrier to form an Ni-W-Pt catalyst with trimetallic sites. The catalyst was found to have a high activity for hydrocarbon conversion under mild conditions. For example, it was applied to the isomerization of n-hexane to obtain a comparatively large yield of branched isomers. However, the specific role of tungsten in the catalyst is difficult to explain. It may function as active sites to catalyze the (de)hydrogenation process or only as a dopant to assist the process. The introduction of a doping effect is specifically described in the next section. Here, we only introduce the use of two or more metal species in the design of catalysts for research on hydroisomerization and the initial results, but the actual effects must be further verified. 2.3 Metal–doping assisted catalytic performance The metal doping effect is a brand-new concept proposed in this review. It relates to some metallic components that have no activities or very low activities for catalytic (de)hydrogenation alone, which are doped into the bifunctional catalyst to improve the function of active metal sites or modify the structure of acid carriers, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance. Structurally, the doped metal may form a mixed state with the active sites or may exist in free state around the active sites. Akhmedov et al. [123] made a similar statement in their review that the introduction of Ni as a second metal into a series of acidic carriers supporting Pt could increase the yield of n-heptane hydroconversion products. However, the characteristic of the introduced second metal having catalytic properties for the host reaction represents the basis for distinguishing between the two concepts of “multi-metal sites” and “doping effect.” The previous studies did not clearly point out the difference between these concepts. In the study of the structural control of metal sites, the formation of multi-metal sites seems to be the reason for the improvement in catalytic performance. In essence, the doping effect can be considered as a positive tuning mechanism of the second metal species to the catalyst body. It is embodied in the following aspects: (1) modifying the geometric arrangement and electronic improvements of active metal sites to enhance its (de)hydrogenation function; (2) competitive adsorption with active metals to change the surface position to improve dispersibility; (3) substituting metal components in the skeleton structure of the acidic carrier to modify the distribution and strength of acid sites; (4) increasing the bonding strength of chemical bonds in the carrier skeleton and polarizing certain active chemical bonds, etc. Although there are also complex interactions between metals in multi-metal sites, it is believed that the contribution of doping effect to the (de)hydrogenation function of active metals is extremely low and can be basically negligible compared with the obvious (de)hydrogeneration property. Therefore, in order to systematically explore the mechanism of metal functions on bifunctional catalysts, we discussed these two concepts separately. We hope the "doping effect" theory can provide new possibilities for subsequent research, and also carry out some work to further deepen it. 2.3.1 Transition metal–doped catalysts In an earlier study, Vázquez et al. [124] synthesized a batch of Ni-Mo/HY catalysts for n-heptane hydroisomerization. The catalyst exhibited the maximum activity when the Ni/(Ni + Mo) ratio was greater than 0.5. It is worth noting that the main role of the Mo species here is to electronically tune the active site Ni. The electrons are transferred from the Mo species to Ni to increase the electron density around Ni and promote the activation and desorption of H to enhance the metal function. This statement was put forward by Wang et al. [125] in a recent study. Pope et al. [126] also observed a similar phenomenon when they added Ni and Zn to a Pt/Y catalyst. Specifically, originally only 0.5 wt% of Pt was supported on the metal sites, and the addition of 1 wt% of the above-mentioned metal increased the activity and isomer selectivity relative to the mono-metal catalyst. However, when the Ni concentration increased from 1 to 3 wt%, the selectivity declined. The cracking reaction increased due to the strong hydrogenolysis of Ni to the CC bond. In this process, Ni as the active metal component catalyzed the (de)hydrogenation course. In addition, Zn could promote the catalyst activity, and this was considered to be caused by the doping effect. Furthermore, the introduction of Zn changed the electron transfer between the metals, reduced the particle size of the active metal component, and improved the dispersibility of the metal component, which in turn influenced the overall properties of the catalyst. Similarly, Akhmedov et al. [123] prepared a new catalyst containing atom-dispersed transition metals using metal vapor synthesis. They generated solvated metal solutions using ruthenium, rhenium, iridium, platinum, nickel, zirconium metal species, and organic ligands (such as butadiene and toluene) through a co-condensation process. The solutions could be directly applied in the synthesis of catalysts for the conversion of n-alkanes under mild conditions, and the results showed outstanding isomers selectivity and low-temperature activity, especially for the isomerization and hydrocracking of long-chain n-alkanes to produce blended gasoline with different octane numbers. Liu et al. [95] prepared a MoP/Hβ catalyst by doping a secondary metal (Cr or Ce) on an Hβ zeolite loaded with molybdenum phosphide via a co-impregnation–temperature-programmed reduction method and investigated the catalytic properties for n-heptane hydroisomerization. Adding the secondary metal additive cerium or chromium to the MoP/Hβ could significantly improve the catalytic activity, and Cr-MoP/Hβ also increased the isomerization selectivity. Under the ideal reaction conditions, the conversion of Cr-MoP40 %/Hβ was 44.9 % and the isomer selectivity was 73.1 %. This is of potential significance to achieve a low-cost n-alkane hydroisomerization process. Liu et al. [127] successfully synthesized a series of highly crystalline and iron-doped ZSM-22 zeolites through an organic structure-directing agent-free route with a small number of precursor suspensions. This is a typical case of doped transition metal–modified acidic supports. The researchers observed that the sample had a uniform morphology and small crystal size. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy technology further confirmed the existence of Fe3+ and the formation of an FeOHSi bridge hydroxyl group inside the zeolite skeleton. The isomorphic substitution of trivalent metal ions (such as Fe instead of Al) in the zeolite skeleton could change the allocation and intensity of acid sites due to the weaker acidity of Fe–OH–Si-bridged hydroxyl groups relative to AlOHSi [128]. The substitution of Al in the skeleton by Fe with a low polarizability reduced the carrier acidity. The reduced acidity of the support resulted in the reduction of the cleavage reaction step at the site. Compared with the Pt/ZSM-22 catalyst, the Fe-doped catalyst Pt/(Al, Fe)-ZSM-22 has a much higher isomerization selectivity because of the more balanced bifunctionality between the BAS and metal sites. The minor crystallite size of the sample also improved the diffusion of intermediates and reduced the production of cracked products. At the same time, it was also observed that even under high-temperature conditions, increasing the substitution degree of Fe could lead to the formation of more di-branched isomers, which significantly inhibited the occurrence of high-temperature cracking and improved the isomerization selectivity for the deep refining of crude oil. The experimental results showed that the Pt dispersion degrees before and after the reaction were similar, confirming that no sintering occurred during the isomerization process. The Pt/(Al, Fe)-ZSM-22 catalyst loaded with 0.5 wt% Pt had the lowest cracking rate, and the isomerization selectivity reached 87.01 % at a high conversion of 90.61 % due to the carrier’s suitable acidity and small crystal size. This discovery provides useful theoretical support for the research on the transition metal doping into the support framework and improving the catalyst performance. Yang and Liu et al. [129–131] applied the doping effect of transition metals Cu and Zn to modify the metal sites of bifunctional catalysts. They synthesized Ni-Cu/SAPO-11 catalysts with copper-doped nickel by a co-impregnation strategy and Pt-Zn/SAPO-11 catalysts with zinc-doped platinum by an incipient wetness method. Fig. 6 shows the schemes of n-octane hydroisomerization over (a) 3Ni/SAPO-11 and (b) 3NixCu/SAPO-11. The catalyst characteristics for n-alkane hydroisomerization were evaluated. The particle size distribution shows that as the Cu loading increased, the particle sizes were chiefly concentrated in the ranges of 6–9 and 9–12 nm, and the mean particle size of the catalyst sample increased with the increase in Cu loading. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy analysis and elemental mapping confirmed that the Ni-Cu alloy was created in the Ni3%Cu1.5 %/SAPO-11. Copper changed the electronic interactions of Ni in the Ni-Cu alloy, reducing the overall ensemble size of Ni, and the introduction of Cu also led to the suppression of the hydrogenolysis reaction of the CC bond promoted by Ni, thereby improving the selectivity to iso-octane. Although the selectivity of the Ni3%Cu1.5 %/SAPO-11 catalyst to iso-octane was slightly lower than that of the catalyst containing 0.5 wt% Pt, when the conversion of Ni3%Cu1.5 %/SAPO-11 was 70 %, the selectivity toward iso-octane was 95 %, which was 19 % higher than that of Ni3%/SAPO-11. The results showed that the doping of Cu had an optimized effect on the catalyst; the catalyst exhibited a better catalytic performance than the mono-metal Ni-based catalysts and has potential application prospects for the process of hydroisomerization. For the zinc-doped Pt-based Pt-Zn/SAPO-11 catalyst, Zn acts as a competitive adsorbent under high-temperature conditions (above 300 °C), changing the Pt position on the surface to make the Pt better dispersed without the occurrence of agglomeration. When the Zn doping amount was 0.7 wt%, zinc provided a desorption transfer site, forming more spilled hydrogen. This promoted the desorption of methylheptane (MMH) and limited the further isomerization of the MMH skeleton. When the zinc content was decreased to 0.5 wt%, the catalyst had the highest selectivity to dimethylhexane (DMH), but the conversion was lower than those of other catalysts. The low conversion was because DMH has a large molecular diameter, and hence, it could not easily diffuse into the pores. This weakened the overall catalytic activity of the catalyst and reduced the n-octane conversion. The results indicated that an appropriate amount of Zn doped into Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst is effective for improving the selectivity of DMHs in n-octane hydroisomerization. DMH diffusion limitations lead to a low activity. Solving the diffusion limitation has always been a key issue in catalyst design. 2.3.2 Main group metal–doped catalysts Using n-hexadecane hydroisomerization as a model process, Sabyrov et al. [132] proved that aluminum-doped mesoporous silica could catalyze the reaction with a very high selectivity (up to 95 %) to generate mono-branched isomers. It is not directly doped with metal aluminum but the form of aluminum compound enters the framework of silica. The main cause of the high selectivity was the mild acidic sites formed by the modification of the silica surface after doping. In addition, the post-synthetic doping strategy enabled the systematic evaluation of the effect of the catalyst microstructure, acid density, and the Pt nanoparticle size on the reaction rate and selectivity. For catalysis involving zeolites, characterizing the above-mentioned features has been very difficult because of the rigid structure of conventional zeolites. Altering the zeolite framework will change its microstructure, crystallinity, and acid site strength and distribution. The analysis of the aluminum-doped mesoporous silica showed that the turnover frequency (TOF) of hydroisomerization linearly increased with the growth of the surface BAS density. Besides generating the largest number of isomers, a catalyst with an increased acid density also highly cleaved n-hexadecane, which may have been due to the increased residence time of the intermediate components on the exterior. The aluminum doping method controlled the isomer selectivity of the acid-catalyzed reaction by adjusting the external acid sites, thereby controlling the residence time of the surface intermediates. In addition, the size of Pt nanoparticles also affected the catalytic performance. The most effective bifunctional catalysts were produced by the smallest Pt nanoparticles, which was likely due to the higher leakage rate into aluminum-doped mesoporous silica, resulting in the addition of more “intimate” metallic and acidic sites [132]. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is a vacuum deposition technique used to deposit atoms on an external surface. In this method, the carrier is alternately exposed to unstable precursors, such as chemical elements and co-reactants. It can be applied to deposit thin layers of oxides, sulfides, nitrides, and metals on miscellaneous carriers. In addition to level surfaces, ALD can also be functionally applied for porous materials to achieve peculiar catalytic reactions. Researchers have extensively studied the incorporation of gallium into the zeolite framework or as a deposited phase of an individual oxide. Geerts et al. [133], inspired by the acid site introduced by Al-ALD, tried to a use tris (2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedionato) gallium (Ga (TMHD)3) precursor and O2 plasma to activate Ga-ALD’s all-silicon zeolite COK-14. They explored the applicability of the ALD strategy for the introduction of metallic and acidic sites in all-silica zeolites. Interestingly, contrary to previous published results for Al-ALD, Geerts et al. found that Ga-ALD was most likely to deposit on the zeolite exterior and edges and caused the preferential deposition of Pt on the catalyst edges. This was due to the optimal proximity between the gallic acid and Pt metal sites, which was conducive to the catalyst activity and selectivity in hydroisomerization, and the maximal isomer yield was about 70 % [133]. Lee et al. [134] explored the hydroisomerization of n-hexadecane on Pt/ZSM-23 by introducing a magnesium (Mg) accelerator. The catalytic performances of Pt/ZSM-23 and Mg-promoted Pt/ZSM-23 catalysts were compared in terms of the correlation between the conversion and selectivity. The Mg additives caused a decrease in the acid amount, but the number of Lewis acid sites increased. The Pt nanoparticle dispersion was also improved; thus, the Mg-promoted catalyst showed a higher yield of iso-hexadecane. Ramos et al. [135] and Liu et al. [136] explored the effect of tin promoters on the hydroisomerization. The introduction of tin at the metal sites of the bifunctional catalyst could also improve the selectivity of the isomerization reaction. 2.3.3 Rare-earth metal–doped catalysts In addition to all the above-mentioned heteroatoms, rare-earth metal atoms have attracted attention because they can improve the zeolite stability. Because rare-earth metals have unfilled 4f electronic orbits and good physical, chemical, optical, and electrical properties, they are often used as structural additives to enhance the activity, selectivity, and thermal stability of various catalysts [137]. In previous studies, post-synthesis methods, including impregnation and ion exchange strategies, are usually employed to introduce heteroatoms. Diverse strategies impact the dispersion and chemical atmosphere of heteroatoms. Liu et al. [138] reported a simple preparation method by mixing a lanthanum precursor with an SAPO-11 precursor, and the effect of the La ions on improving the catalyst stability was studied. In the cracking process of n-dodecane, although there were no active metal sites, the La/SAPO-11 catalyst with moderately acidic sites could still improve the isomerization performance (the yield of iso-paraffin was increased by 9.5 % compared with the traditional method) and suppress the occurrence of cracking reactions. La ions in the synthetic gel could accelerate the interaction between the precursor suspension materials, form a layered structure, and collapse during the crystallization process. In addition, La ions could prevent the zeolite framework from deforming under high-temperature and hydrothermal conditions. The BAS retention rate after hydrothermal treatment was very high (up to 45.5 %). Moreover, the La ions also improved the depolymerization of P species and reciprocity between P and Al species. When Si and La ions coexisted, La ions could not be incorporated into the zeolite skeleton. In addition, the P atoms in LaPO4 participated in the formation of the zeolite framework. One coordination PO bond in the PO4 3− tetrahedron (Fig. 7 ) consisted of electrons provided individually by P atoms. When the PO4 3− tetrahedron was associated with the zeolite framework through the AlOP bond, oxygen atoms had an electron-donating effect on the P atoms, and the increase in the electron cloud density of the P atoms produced a shielding effect. LaPO4 retained the framework structure to prevent a steam attack. In addition, [La(OH)2] + compensated for the structural tension and increased the Al–O bonding intensity, thereby suppressing the desiliconization reaction during heat treatment. Experimental results showed that La ions could polarize the CH bonds, thereby enhancing the (de)hydrogenation. The polarization effect reduced the reaction energy barrier for paraffin wax to convert into carbocations for isomerization. However, the excess introduction of La ions increased the number of Lewis acid sites, thereby reducing the selectivity to iso-alkanes [138]. The result of adding La to modify the structure of the SAPO-11 molecular sieve is of great significance for the application of molecular sieves in harsh environments. The rare-earth metal La can not only adjust the structure of the acidic carrier but also act on the metal sites to improve the (de)hydrogenation of the bifunctional catalyst. Song et al. [139] prepared a La-Ni/S2O8 2--ZrO2-Al2O3 (La-Ni-SZA) catalyst and investigated the effects of La and Ni on the catalyst structure and isomerization properties. The addition of La could improve the dispersibility of the metal and promote the redox properties of the catalyst and the formation of Lewis acid centers. The highest yield of iso-pentane by La-Ni-SZA could reach 66.5 % at low temperatures, which was mainly due to the synergy between La and Ni. Decolatti et al. [140] investigated a similar example, in which La ions were added into the H-mordenite molecular sieve. Compared with H-mordenite, the La ions in the La/H-mordenite prevented the formation of an additional Al skeleton after treatment for 25 h at 500 °C in 10 % water. Furthermore, Shao et al. [23] found that surficial Ce could protect the framework of the MCM-48 zeolite and prevent water vapor corrosion. In the presence of fluoride ions, Ce/MCM-48 could preserve the mesoporous framework in boiling water for 36 h. Although it is difficult to draw conclusions about the mechanism and effect of rare-earth modification for molecular sieves with various topologies, rare-earth metals have wide applicability for improving the (hydro)thermal stabilities of zeolites. Some of the cases of metal doping described in this section are presented in Table 4 . 3 Factors affecting the metal function The previous section mainly introduced the diversity of metal species at the metal sites that control the (de)hydrogenation functions in the bifunctional catalysts for n-alkane hydroisomerization. Compared with the isomerization function of the main skeleton provided by acid sites, the variety of metal sites also has an indispensable effect on the catalytic performance. Similarly, the synergy between the two types of active sites in terms of the balance and proximity is also very important. To further explore the catalytic performance of the bifunctional catalyst, it is often necessary to explore the control of functional sites on specific characteristics through the reaction mechanism of the bifunctional catalyst and perform a catalyst test, which is an “inside–outside” approach to explain the experimental phenomena, combined with a large number of characterization methods. For the functional metal sites mainly discussed in this review, the main factors affecting their function are the metal site size and dispersity, crystal plane orientation, and the synergistic effects between metal and acid sites. 3.1 Influence of size and dispersity Based on the studies of the metal sites in the past decades, the research on noble metal sites is trending toward the use of low load, high dispersion, and nanoparticles. Based on the bifunctional catalytic mechanism, take the Pt-based catalyst as an example, the nano-size and high dispersion of Pt can efficiently improve the contact between Pt and BAS. Hence, the iso-olefin intermediate formed at the acid sites can easily spread to the Pt sites, thereby completing the hydrogenation reaction. In the study of Pt metal sites for bifunctional catalysts used in hydroisomerization reactions, to obtain excellent performance of the catalytic reaction, the loading amount of noble metal sites should be at least 0.5 wt% and generally not higher than 1 wt%. Such a low amount is used not only based on the cost but also because too high of a metal load will lead to agglomeration and destroy the balance of metal–acid sites. Therefore, it is generally agreed upon that highly dispersed nanoparticles should be used at the metal sites, and the high dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on bifunctional catalysts has also become a popular development trend in industry. Wang et al. [54] established two models of Pt nanoparticles with the sizes of 1.1 and 2.9 nm, corresponding to Pt nanoparticles on metal sites of V-0.15 Pt/S-11 prepared by a vacuum-assisted strategy and I-0.15 Pt/S-11 catalysts prepared by the conventional impregnation method, respectively. By comparing the Pt nanoparticles on the metal sites of these two systems, the relationship between the two Pt nanoparticle models and the percentage of exposed atoms could be obtained. Specifically, the percentage of bare atoms (73.68 %) to Pt clusters with sizes of 1.1 nm was about 1.2 times higher than that of bare atoms to Pt particles with a size of 2.9 nm, and the dispersion of Pt clusters reached 73.34 %. As a result, the Pt clusters contained more active sites, resulting in a stronger (de)hydrogenation activity and the production of more olefin intermediates to achieve higher conversion. Compared with large Pt particles, small Pt clusters could also produce appropriate H-spill effects, thus further enhancing their activities [141]. Furthermore, the firm reciprocity between Pt clusters and carriers will decrease the reducibility of Pt species with relatively-electron-insufficient structures, thereby accelerating the hydrogen adsorption and leading to high hydrogenation activity [142,143]. However, researchers should not blindly pursue the reduction of metal particle size. An et al. [53] used polystyrene microspheres as hard templates to synthesize a batch of macroporous oxides TiO2, Al2O3, Nb2O5, ZrO2, and Ta2O5 with high crystallinity (Fig. 8 , mean pore diameter of 300 nm). Then colloidal Pt nanoparticles with sizes of 1.7, 2.7 and 5.5 nm were loaded a content of 0.5 wt% on macroporous oxides. Hence, it can be applied to study the Pt particle size- and carrier-dependent catalytic selectivity and reaction mechanism in n-hexane isomerization. The results showed that Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt/Ta2O5 had the highest isomerization selectivity. The stable charge enabled Nb2O5 and Ta2O5 to promote the electron transfer to Pt nanoparticles, and a higher electron density was formed. Thus, they had a higher isomerization selectivity than other carriers. The smaller Pt nanoparticles had higher TOFs and stronger metal functions. Therefore, many researchers have applied considerable effort to design Pt nanoparticles with smaller particle sizes, even sub-nanoparticles [144]. However, in the study, the 5.5-nm Pt nanoparticles with larger particle sizes deposited on Nb2O5 or Ta2O5 had the highest selectivity for isomerization of about 97 %, because of their abundant terrace sites. As the particle size of Pt increased from 1.7 to 5.5 nm, the yield of isomers also improved. The metal function is dependent on multiple factors, and smaller metal particles on the bifunctional catalyst are not necessarily better. In addition to the study of catalyst materials, controlling conditions in the preparation process, especially the calcination temperature, can also significantly affect the metal particle size and dispersion. Graaf et al. [145] reported that improper calcination conditions will result in poor metal particle dispersibility because the mobility of Pt compounds in this stage is too high. In all stages of the preparation process, the mobility of the Pt compound is maintained as low as possible. This is not only to attain a catalyst with high Pt dispersibility but also because this movability may cause the Pt particles to migrate to an undesirable region. Similarly, Smirnova et al. [146] found that the calcination temperature had a significant influence on the catalytic performance in a series of bifunctional catalysts prepared by impregnating SAPO-31 with an H2PtCl6 solution. Specifically, the calcination of H2PtCl6 precursors at different temperatures could produce three decomposition products: PtCl4 was mainly generated below 350 °C, PtCl2 was mainly obtained in the range of 350–415 °C, and Pt was obtained at 510 °C. Regarding the Pt/SAPO-31 catalyst calcined below 280 °C, further hydrogen reduction of PtCl4 produced a large amount of HCl, which destroyed the structure of the SAPO-31 carrier and caused metal–acid function imbalance.
