If the calcination temperature was increased above 550 °C, the H2PtCl6 precursor was directly converted into larger-sized Pt particles or aggregated Pt clusters. Different Pt states existed in different temperature ranges, which agreed with the oxidation decomposition data of H2PtCl6 from a previous study [147]. Therefore, higher iso-paraffin yields could only be obtained on samples calcined at 450–550 °C. Excessively high or low calcination temperatures resulted in a significant decrease in the yield of iso-alkanes in the final product. This is caused by the poor (de)hydrogenation ability of the catalyst due to the reduced Pt dispersibility. It was shown that although the chemical compositions of the Pt1%/SAPO-31 catalyst precursor were the same under different calcination temperatures, the difference in the calcination temperature during the preparation process led to a significant difference between the Pt particle size, dispersion degree, and surface acidity of SAPO-31. Generally, in applications, most bifunctional catalysts should feature metal sites with high dispersion and nanoparticles. Good dispersion will directly improve the product yield of isomers. In addition to the regulation of particle size, researchers can also design new carriers to provide additional metal sites and regulate the synthesis conditions as a breakthrough to improve metal dispersion. 3.2 Influence of crystal plane orientation In addition to the size and dispersion of Pt nanoparticles, the function of the metal sites is also closely related to the crystallographic orientation of the plane over the metal particles [148]. The crystal plane orientation is related to the valence state of the active metal element in the precursor used. There are some differences in the effects of different precursors on the catalyst performance. Tsung et al. [149] discovered two stages to simultaneously control the size and shape of Pt nanocubes and nanopolyhedrons with adjustable sizes from 5 to 9 nm. In the first period, the nucleation rate that determines the number of nuclei is hinged on the oxidation state of the metal precursor. The shape of the secondary period is controlled by adjusting the growth kinetics of the reaction temperature. Lee et al. [150] explained how to control the catalyst selectivity by controlling the particles shape. The kinetics data of the catalyst made of dispersed tetrahedral Pt nanoparticles confirmed that Pt nanoparticles with the [111] crystal plane could facilitate the isomerization selectivity of the trans structure to the cis counterparts, and on a more open surface, the selectivity was the opposite. Quantum mechanics calculations indicated that the additional stability of cis-olefins visibly shown on the H-saturated Pt [111] surface was attributed to a small degree of surface reconstruction, causing the olefins to adsorb on closely packed Pt surfaces. However, on a more open surface, the tendency was opposite. This study concluded that the reason the surface reconstruction played a core role in determining the adsorption energy of 2-butene on the Pt surface might be steric effects, which were related to the need to accommodate a larger volume of methyl terminal groups on the surface [150]. Performing a density functional theory (DFT) calculation and decomposing the adsorption energy into the three parts (Fig. 9 ) can better clarify the factors controlling selectivity at the molecular level: (1) the deformation energy of the molecule Edef(molec), (2) the deformation energy of the surface Edef(surf), and (3) the stable two-electron interaction energy (Einteraction). According to DFT calculations, for the case of trans-2-butene, some molecules must twist around the central carbon–carbon bonds [151]. It can be further demonstrated that using a more open surface can diminish this effect, in which case it is more likely to form thermodynamically favorable trans isomers after adsorption. Many researchers have studied the effects of different metal precursors on the properties of catalysts in n-alkane hydroisomerization. Aristizábal et al. [152] pointed out that replacing Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 with H2PtCl6 as the precursor produces more dispersed Pt nanoparticles and more-active catalysts. However, Samad et al. [30] found that Pt based on Pt(NH3)4 2+ ions will generate small Pt particles during the impregnation process, while negatively charged PtCl6 2− ions will form larger Pt nanoparticles because the ion exchange at the acid sites is restricted. This also verified that smaller metal nanoparticles are not necessarily better, as addressed in the previous section. Because the factors affecting the catalytic performance are diverse, the sizes of the metal particles should also have an optimal range. In the industry, the form of anionic precursors is more common in the loading of noble metals, especially in the presence of competing anions (eg.NO3−) to prevent the uneven distribution of metal particles on the carriers [153–155]. However, a small number of metal species derived from cationic precursors can also be deposited in the corresponding area of the carriers by adjusting the pH value of the system and also have well dispersibility [30]. Wang et al. [148] prepared ZSM-22 zeolites with 0.5 wt% Pt by impregnation using different precursors—H2PtCl6, Pt(NO3)2, Pt(NH3)4Cl2, (NH4)2PtCl4—to explore the effect of the precursor on the activity of Pt/ZSM-22 bifunctional catalysts for n-hexadecane hydroisomerization. The authors found that among all the Pt/ZSM-22 catalysts tested, the catalyst prepared using an H2PtCl6 precursor showed the highest metal dispersion and the best catalytic performance. This was ascribed to the change in the valence states of the Pt ions in various precursors, which could determine both the particle size of the reduced Pt nanoparticles and the crystal plane orientation. The reduced Pt nanoparticles derived from the Pt (IV) precursor grew along the [011] crystal axis, and the Pt [111] corner point was more active. In contrast, Pt nanoparticles formed using Pt (II) precursors grew along the [001] axis, thus generating more Pt [100] planes. Moreover, because of the formation of defect sites and amended hydrogenation, the activity and selectivity of hydroisomerization on the Pt [111] surface were superior to those on the Pt [100] surface. The Pt precursors with different valence states resulted in particle distribution of different sizes. The particle size of the metal nanoparticles obtained by the reduction of the Pt (IV) precursor was slightly smaller than those obtained by the reduction of Pt (II). This was because the Pt (IV) precursor led to vastly dispersed and smaller Pt nanoparticles, while the Pt (II) precursor was more conducive to the formation of larger and poorly dispersed Pt particles, especially under the condition of automatic reduction during calcination. The impact of the valence state of Pt in the precursor on the dispersion and particle sizes of the metal particles on the catalyst after reduction can cause differences in the coordination number of Pt with diverse valence states. Some reports indicate that the Pt (II) amine complex with a coordination number of four will form a fluid intermediate substance, which may be in the form of [Pt (NH3)2H2], and the particles will easily to agglomerate, resulting in a decrease in the Pt dispersion and a large particle size. In contrast, Pt (IV) with a coordination number of six tends to form [PtOxCly] species on the catalyst surface during calcination to increase the distribution of Pt on the metal sites of the reduced catalyst [152,156]. A few other studies [157,158] also indicated that the square planar complex of Pt (e.g., [Pt(NH3)4]2+) has a lower metal dispersion than the octahedral complex (e.g., [PtCl6]2+), because the latter is maintained on a support with a higher efficiency [148]. Moreover, the catalysts of Pt octahedral nanoparticles mainly wrapped by Pt [111] crystal planes have a higher conversion rate of n-alkanes and a higher selectivity toward iso-hydrocarbons than catalysts of spherical and cubic Pt containing more Pt [100] planes; this is because the corresponding Pt surface or Pt [111] crystal plane in the Pt phase has more active-external-defect sites and more activated hydrogen [158]. Furthermore, because of the smaller particle sizes and higher distribution of the Pt nanoparticles located in anionic precursors, such as H2PtCl6 and (NH4)2PtCl4, exhibit better reactivities than those located in cationic precursors (Pt (NH3)4Cl2). Overall, the catalytic activity hinges to a great extent on the structures and sizes of the Pt particles after reduction, and this is likely related to the type of Pt precursor. To develop an effective catalyst with a smaller particle size and more [111] bare surfaces, the Pt species in the precursor should be Pt (IV) situated at the anion site. 3.3 Synergistic effect between metal and acid sites The synergistic effect between the two functional sites on the bifunctional catalyst is a particularly important and high-profile concern in catalyst design, and it mainly involves the nMs/nAs ratio and the intimacy degree between the two sites. A proper nMs/nAs ratio and proximity are common characteristics of catalysts with superior yield and selectivity. Regarding the nMs/nAs ratio, Alvarez et al. [8] reported that when a metal/acid site ratio of 0.03 is reached, the conversion activity of n-alkanes increases linearly. This indicates that the metal acts as a rate-limiting site, and the bifunctional mechanism is mainly triggered when this ratio is reached. Below this ratio, the reaction rate occurring at acid sites is limited. Above this ratio, activity is only controlled by the density of the acid sites, and the isomerization at BAS is the rate-limiting step. When the nMs/nAs value is in the range of 0.1–0.15, the catalyst can behave as a model bifunctional catalyst [73,159]. As Guisnet et al. [159] emphasized, with regard to isomerization selectivity, the ideal catalyst depends not only on nMs/nAs but also on the number of acid sites between the two metal sites, which should be sufficiently low to block the resorption of the isomerized olefin intermediates on the acid sites and its further isomerization or cracking reactions. Through the study of the metal selective deposition mentioned above, Samad et al. [160] investigated the proximity of metal–acid sites on atomic, nanometer, micron, and millimeter scales (Fig. 10 ). Atomic and nanoscale affinities were attained by loading Pt on an acidic silica–alumina carrier (Pt/Si-Al). The affinities were extended to the micrometer and millimeter scales, respectively, by a physical mixing method and the separation of the non-acidic Pt/silica and metal-free silica-alumina layers. The results showed that the Pt/Si-Al catalyst with a low metal dispersion at the nanometer scale exhibited higher bifunctional properties than that with high metal dispersion at the atomic scale. The former also maintained intimacy at the micron scale; the intimacy was only destroyed at the millimeter scale. When nAs/nMs < 10, the TOFs of all the bifunctional catalysts for iso-heptane products were similar to that of metal monofunctional catalysts. When nAs/nMs > 10, the TOF of iso-heptane increased, which confirmed that a bifunctional reaction occurred that was similar to the limit value proposed by Alvarez [8]. There were very few acid sites in the “effective radius” between the two Pt nanoparticles. Thus, it was difficult for the catalyst to show bifunctionality. Therefore, each metal site required a minimum number of acid sites to completely inhibit the monofunctional pathway. Each metal center seemed able to supply hundreds of acidic sites without affecting the reaction rate, which also verified the high (de)hydrogenation activities of Pt species [74]. As early as 1962, Weisz et al. [161] proposed an “intimacy criterion” for the maximum distance between two active sites, and beyond this distance the catalytic activity would decrease; this is because if the distance was too large, the diffusion path of the olefin intermediate at the acid site will increase and lead to a secondary reaction, which tends to produce cracked products or even light gases and coke. In many studies, the metal sites of catalysts have been designed to be close as possible to acid sites, especially in the case of metals dispersed in acid zeolites [4,162]. Concerning the effect of particle size on activity, many studies also tend to produce metal species with smaller particles, because the smaller the particle size is, the easier it is for the metal nanoparticles to be uniformly dispersed on the carrier, resulting in closer proximity to the acid sites. However, due to technological limitations, quantitative research on proximity could only be carried out at the macroscale (tens of microns or even larger) in the past few decades [74,163]. Therefore, regarding the intimacy of the two active sites on the bifunctional catalyst, it is generally believed that having closer active sites is better. In recent years, with the evolution and progress of science and technology, there has been a newer understanding of the impact of the nanoscale metal–acid site intimacy on product selectivity. The intimacy criterion is indeed connected with the catalyst activity, but the general perception of closer being better has encountered challenges. Höchtl et al. [164] pointed out that at the nanometer scale, when the metal and zeolite are in straight contact, the proximity between the metal and the acid site has little effect on the n-heptane hydroisomerization. Zečević et al. [165] and Cheng et al. [166], from the same research organization, achieved a unique metal–acid site proximity at the nanometer scale by selectively positioning Pt nanoparticles on alumina binders or zeolite crystals. The results showed that the catalyst with Pt positioned on the binder provided a nanometer distance between the Pt nanoparticles and the acid sites, while the catalyst with Pt sites inside the zeolite crystal provided the closest proximity. However, contrary to the intimacy criterion, encapsulating Pt particles in narrow zeolite micropore channels will promote cracking reactions. As a result, at the nanometer scale, the smaller the distance between the metal–acid sites is, the less favorable the progress of the isomerization reaction becomes. Because Pt loading occupies a certain spatial position within the zeolite crystals, diffusion restrictions are imposed on the olefin intermediates, leading to secondary cracking reactions, especially for zeolite crystals with narrow pores. Moussa et al. [167] explored another intimacy relationship of metal–acid sites by preparing nano- and micro-scale β-alumina supports and selectively forming targeted Pt nanoparticles in the alumina region or zeolite crystals. After the calcination step, the nanoscale intimacy of the composite material formed by heterogeneous aggregation was retained, while the composite material synthesized by wet mechanical mixing showed hundreds of nanodomains, indicating that the zeolite and alumina were separated from each other. Regarding the selective deposition mechanism targeting Pt species, many experimental schemes have employed Pt precursors with opposite charges [165–167]. The precursor that targets the alumina region is generally negatively charged [PtCl6]2−. Furthermore, in Moussa et al.’s study, under low-pH conditions, strong electrostatic adsorption occurred between a negatively charged [PtCl6]2− ion and a positively charged alumina surface, as the point of zero charge of alumina was ca. 9 [167]. In contrast, the precursors that were selectively deposited in the zeolite region were generally positively charged Pt coordination compounds. The adsorption occurred under the condition of pH ≈ 5, and an ion-exchange process occurred between the proton of the zeolite and the positively charged Pt coordination compounds. In such a pH range, the adsorption of cationic complexes on the silanol groups on the alumina surface and the zeolite particle outer surfaces was also negligible because the alumina surfaces were positively charged [30]. According to the results of the catalyst test, at the same conversion rate, the selectivity toward the isomerized products decreased sequentially in the order of Pt/A-nm composite material (Pt deposited in the alumina region, heterogeneous coagulation), Pt/Z-nm composite material (Pt deposited in the zeolite area, heterogeneous coagulation), Pt/A-μm composite material (Pt deposited in the alumina area, wet physical mixing), and Pt/Z-μm composite material (Pt deposited in the zeolite area, wet physical mixing). This result also showed that the closer the metal–acid sites were at the nanometer scale, the less favorable the isomerization reaction was. In summary, the selectivity of the catalyst could be adjusted by controlling the nanoscale spatial structure on the bifunctional catalyst, and the intimacy of the metal–acid sites cannot be generalized as “the closer the better,” but should be in a reasonable range. 4 Concluding remarks This review summarizes and discusses the function and influence of metals on bifunctional catalysts for n-alkane hydroisomerization. The metal function is directly related to the metal types, and the structural control of the metal sites can also directly affect the bifunctional catalyst’s overall performance. Various types of metal species supported on acidic materials have been investigated. Noble metals of Pt and Pd are still the most extensively used metal components in industrial n-alkane hydroisomerization because of their powerful (de)hydrogenation function and superior stability. However, the economic problems caused by the costs of catalysts containing noble metals have forced researchers to channel their attention to non-noble metal species. Among them, Ni is the most widely used metal species. However, the (de)hydrogenation function of Ni is weaker than that of noble metals. To obtain sufficient functional metal sites, a large number of metal particles must be loaded on the carrier, resulting in metal agglomeration and poor dispersion. The high loading will also block the pores of the acidic carrier and affect its isomerization function. In addition, due to the weak toxicity resistance of Ni and the strong hydrogenolysis ability of the CC bonds, the reaction tends to yield cracked products. To overcome these problems, developing novel preparation strategies to reduce the particle sizes of non-noble metals and enhance the interactions between metals and carriers to suppress metal aggregation has become a research breakthrough. The tentative application of transition metal compounds in bifunctional catalysts provides potential options for reducing the cost of preparation. Owing to the ligand and ensemble effect of phosphorus, it shows a weaker hydrogenolysis capacity on the CC bonds and better toxicity resistance. Transition metal phosphide has a high chemical stability and remarkable electrical and thermal conductivities, and it is expected to become the next-generation hydroconversion catalyst for oil refining. Metal borides have attracted increasing attention because of their classic structural features of long-range disorder, distinct isotropic structures, and abundant coordinatively unsaturated sites that can supply a uniform environment for the dispersion of active sites. Transition metal oxides, represented by molybdenum oxide, are also important compounds in catalytic reactions. Inserting hydrogen atoms into the lattice of MoO3 will result in the formation of MoO x H y with enhanced hydroisomerization activity. Transition metal sulfides used as HDS catalysts can convert linear olefins to branched olefins and then hydrogenate to iso-alkanes to minimize the loss of octane number. In addition to mono-metal sites, multi-metal sites modify the geometric arrangement and electronic properties of the components because of the close interaction between multiple metal components, so that the catalyst exhibits higher catalytic performance. The application of bifunctional catalysts based on multi-metals has been considered to be an effective strategy to achieve ideal catalysts. An important point of this review is that a new concept of the doping effect is proposed based on the observation that some metal components have no activities or very low activities for (de)hydrogenation alone, which are doped into the bifunctional catalyst to improve the function of active metal sites or modify the structure of acid carriers, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance. The doping metals include 1) transition metals such as copper, zinc, and iron; 2) main group metals such as aluminum, gallium, magnesium, and tin; 3) rare-earth metals such as lanthanum and cerium. Both the metal-doping effect and the metal–acid synergistic effect can significantly impact the catalyst properties. The purpose of this review is to propose a “metal-doping effect” theory to provide a potential explanation for previous and subsequent research. The main factors that affect the functions of metals are also discussed, and they can be summarized as the particle size and dispersibility, crystal plane orientation, and synergistic effects between metal and acid sites. The particle size should be within reasonable range of values, rather than generalizing that smaller is better. If it is too large, agglomeration will easily occur and block the pores, while a size that is too small will cause a low local concentration and insufficient metal function. The crystal plane orientation can be explained from the perspective of microscopic quantum science. Because the corresponding Pt surface or Pt [111] plane in the Pt phase has more activated surface defect sites and more activated hydrogen to facilitate the reaction, the Pt in the precursor should be Pt (IV) located at the anionic sites. A proper nMs/nAs ratio and proximity are common characteristics of catalysts with high n-paraffin conversion and iso-paraffin selectivity because of the synergistic effect between the two sites. In terms of the isomerization selectivity, the ideal catalyst depends not only on nMs/nAs but also on the number of acid sites between two metal sites. The ideal state can only be achieved when the quantity of acid sites between the two metal sites is sufficiently low to restrict the resorption of the olefin intermediates on the acid sites and the occurrence of further isomerization or cracking reactions. The advanced studies have shown that the distance between metal–acid sites should also be within a reasonable range, rather than following the simple criterion that closer is better. Too large of a distance will increase the time for the olefin intermediate to diffuse to the metal sites and cause cracking reactions. If the distance is too close at the nanometer scale, Pt loading will occupy a certain space in the zeolite crystals, which imposes diffusion restrictions on the olefin intermediates, resulting in secondary cracking reactions, especially for zeolite crystals with narrow pores. Hence, the catalyst selectivity can be adjusted by controlling the nanoscale spatial structure on the bifunctional catalyst. In addition to the production of high-end fuels and lubricants in modern coal chemical and petrochemical industry, hydroisomerization is also commonly used in sustainable renewable energy field [146]. e.g. hydrotreating of vegetable oils [168,169], hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA) [170]. The production of green diesel and HEFA jet fuel through the hydrotreatment of biomass oils and then hydroisomerization of bio-n-alkanes is one of the most developing and promising technologies for obtaining biofuels. For example, sunflower oil can synthesize iso-alkanes that can be used as high-quality diesel oil through hydrodeoxygenation and hydroisomerization processes [171]. Furthermore, bio-degradable base oil that quickly reduces environmental pollution, which is a category V lubricant under the classification of API, is becoming increasingly popular. As all industrial companies in the world today are seeking measures to reduce environmental pollution, which can be attained by utilizing these “natural” oils. Thus, although the cost of biomass oils is high, the additional cost is sufficient to offset the environmental management costs caused by the use of other mineral oils and synthetic lubricants. Therefore, n-alkane hydroisomerization is a long-lasting industrial oil refining technology that continuously adapts to the current trends. It can produce a series of high-quality and environmentally friendly chemical products that benefit the environment and society. This review only explains the effect of (de)hydrogenation on the catalyst performance from the perspective of metal function, but numerous researchers are devoted to the design of new carriers. Among such carriers, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline porous solids constructed by the three-dimensional connection of metal ion nodes through organic linkers. Owing to their large external areas, controllable pore sizes, adjustable chemical compositions, surface functionalities, and good metal positions, MOF performances in a few crucial gas storage and molecular separation applications have begun to rival those of conventional microporous solids, such as zeolites and activated carbon. Therefore, MOFs can be designed to contain coordinatively unsaturated metal centers, which can be used as adsorption or catalytic centers for small molecules. Moreover, MOFs can be used as high-specific-surface-area supports for dispersing or coating catalytic active sites, such as metal or metal oxide nanoclusters, organometallic complexes, biomolecules, and enzymes. This application approach may enable MOFs to become potential carriers for bifunctional catalysts [172]. In addition to MOFs, ionic liquids are also one of the new green alternatives to conventional porous materials. Because of their high ionic conductivity, stability at high temperature and in air, low saturated vapor pressure, low volatility and high acidity, they can be carried out in a liquid-liquid two-phase reaction mode under extremely mild conditions and reduce cracking reaction. The ionic liquids are coated on the surface of the noble-metal-supported porous materials to form a metal-based ionic liquid film layer, which can promote diffusion and mass transfer. And convenient recovery, can prolong the use cycle of the catalyst, is in line with the current environment-friendly concept of new carriers [173,174]. We have made considerable achievements in n-alkane hydroisomerization. Our attention is on the value-added utilization of downstream products in the modern coal chemical industry, which are currently developing quickly in the world. The research by our group comprises the following subjects. 1) The synthesis of a hierarchical SAPO-11 molecular sieves through solvent-free methods. Enhanced isomerization selectivity on n-hexadecane hydroisomerization was realized [175]. 2) The addition of graphene oxide in the reaction system of SAPO-11 preparation. A well-crystallized SAPO-11 support with more acidic sites was achieved, which exhibited superior catalytic activity for n-dodecane hydroisomerization. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism was proposed. The superior activity was mainly attributed to the interactions between graphene oxide and the structure-directing agent and the formation of hydrogen and amide bonds [176]. 3) The construction of a novel metal pre-loading method. The product yield of the catalyst could be greatly increased because of the interaction between Pt and the lone-pair electrons of organic amines, and a better metal–acid balance could be obtained. The main purpose of the current paper was to explore the catalyst design for the hydroisomerization of F–T waxes and to produce high-value products such as base oil and high-density diesel [177]. This review is a systematic summary of the properties of metal sites on bifunctional catalysts for n-alkane hydroisomerization to lay a foundation for the future design of catalysts for the isomerization of wax oil derived from the coal chemical industry. At the same time, it provides some perspectives for the design of ideal bifunctional catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The Fischer–Tropsch process is a technical route for the indirect liquefaction of coal in the modern coal chemical industry and also an important means of producing high-value-added products in the coal chemical industry. The market demand for the main product Fischer–Tropsch wax (n-alkane content up to 95 %) is limited, resulting in an overcapacity. The hydroisomerization process can transform Fischer–Tropsch waxes into a low-freezing-point oil-phase mixtures, which can be used as a high-end lubricating base oils to solve the imbalance between supply and demand in the market and expand the comprehensive utilization of coal chemical resources. However, the complex synergistic effects between metal and acid sites and the diffusion limitations of olefin intermediates are major challenges in the design of the bifunctional catalysts. Unlike the majority of studies that focused on analyzing the isomerization functions of acidic carriers, in this review, we focused on the types of metal sites and the factors affecting the metal function of bifunctional catalysts used in n-alkane hydroisomerization in recent years. We introduce bifunctional catalysts supporting different metal types, including noble metals, transition metals and their compounds, bimetallic sites, and other catalyst types. In particular, the “doping effect” of the second metal is, for the first time, proposed to explain its role on the catalyst body, and the effects of the metal particle size and dispersion, crystal plane orientation, metal/acid site ratio, and the distance between the metal and acid sites on the hydrogenation function are also discussed. The summary of previous research shows that the types and structural control of metal sites have greatly improved the performance of n-alkane hydroisomerization over bifunctional catalysts. This provides an important reference for the structural design of new bifunctional catalysts in the future and for catalyst application in the hydroisomerization of Fischer–Tropsch waxes.
coredata.dc:title: Species and impacts of metal sites over bifunctional catalyst on long chain n-alkane hydroisomerization: A review
